name: Carpe Diem
description: In this very short kinetic novel, you will play as Jung who's meeting up and hanging out with a girl named Ai. Spend your time wisely.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP1 Processor: Pentium 4 1.7 GHz Memory: 128 MB RAM Graphics: Intel integrated chipset Storage: 88 MB available space

reviews.review_text: My first date ever was with an anime girl.
i will not let her go!

CARPE DIEM VISUAL NOVEL FAST REVIEW (NO SPOILERS)  I liked it. Not heaps, but it was ok.   -The story only went for around 7min's (i'm not the fastest reader, but i wouldn't say i'm a slow reader either, so i'm maybe average??), but i was entertained for those 7min's, & thats what matters. It even surprised me at the end, which is always a bonus. -If you look at the art/ graphics on the store page, you've pretty much seen the art/ graphics for the whole game. I think there were 4-5 different backgrounds, with each background showing the same character, who's only variety was when she'd open & close her mouth during dialogue, as well as the occasional blink. Oh, sorry, i forgot, her cheeks also get red at times. -The music was fine. Mellow piano playing, but for only 7min's, so i didn't get sick of it.  So, the game altogether was ok. Nothing blow-away spectacular, but all in all, a good experience. Maybe if it was longer, i wouldn't have liked it as much.  Also, i haven't mentioned, this VN was the maker's first effort & it's free, so i think you've got to allow for that as well. I'd rather make an average first game than a crappy one, & this isn't crappy (just average).   5/10
The developer of Ai knows how to fix crash better than the developers of Batman: Arkham Knight

7.5/10 - This Game is Annoying until the Very End...  The game itself is not great; but once completed you develop a new appreciation for this title. It only took me 11 minutes to complete and I'm slow at reading. There is only 1 ending since this is a 'Kinetic Novel'; and once completed you earn the achievement. Another easy 100% Achievement here!  This game definitely is more than meets the eye. If you like visual novels I'd definitely give this game a try.   It's FREE; so give this a try!     Accidently Reviewed

This is honestly one of the deepest games of 2017. I have never before experienced a game of such depth and emotion until Carpe Diam. It was about 10 minutes in when I realized that I had things to do today, but I was instead staying in my basement playing video games making no real impact in the world. For lunch today I had ramen noodles. The main protagonist, Jung, enjoys rice, and I too enjoy rice. This connection really made me feel immersed in this universe. When I grow up I know for a fact that I will be a better father and husband than my dad ever was because of this story. Unlike Mike. Mike was always there just to be a jerk to me. I hate Mike. Now he lives a sad life without Julia. Because Julia is mine, Mike. She's mine and you can't have her! 4/5

This game is great and teaches us all a lesson. That your Wifu isn't real and reality needs a check, and that I rather be in this world than the world I am in. I need a teleporter into that world, PRONTO!

So, speaking as a fellow dev and Renpy user, I have A LOT to say about this, so I'll try to break it up a bit.  Visuals: They're great. It looked professional and clean. The only complaint I have isn't even really a complaint at all: get some more. Maybe some different poses for Ai or more backgrounds so you can actually be in the different stores. What I would really want is to get to actually see Ai in the dress. However, its still a first game. And one heck of an amazing at that, so I cannot fault you at all.  Story: Dear god, that killed me at the end. All three times. Really well written, no grammar/spelling errors that I saw and really good ending. Really all you can ask.  Overall, this game is amazing and a must-play for everyone pretty much ever. 10/10, would cry over again.
10/10 made me kill my whole family    would do it again...   ~a small loan of a million memes

This game really did touch my heart with such a twisting and rivoting story with an ending that could have never been suspected this visual novel really threw me in a tizzy. It makes you ask yourself what you really are doing with your pitiful and insginificant life. Who could have guessed that the character named AI was an actual AI in a computer game. I found myself connecting with her and then became emotionally unstable once I found out the truth. I spiraled into a deprtession turning to alcohol for the support that my beloved AI could not lend me since she was forever sealed away in the virtual world. I love AI and one day I will make her real so we can continue our life together at the mall buying gtx titans, spider keychains and slamming each other over the head due to our excessive tilt from street fighter at the arcade.

Wow this game is an amzing game! It really made me thnk, 'What am I doing with my life' and 'What do I want to do'? This game asks the gritty reality question a lot of people ignore. I can say I recommend this game to anyone having a hard time in life looking for an answer or simply wants to think for a solid 20 minutes while looking at Ai. I guess the real question is though do you want to go to the Arcade, Mall, or Park? Choosing one of these 3 simple questions could define your life very easily. Are you a nature person, choose the park! Do you like videogames, well take your waifu with you! Do you think waifu will want some new clothes, take her to the mall! I can strongly give this game a 9/11 being that its a real smack to the face to any fat weeaboos who think they are all that and a bag of Funyuns.  Final verdict 9/11  Decerex with love XOXO

Carpe Diem is pretty much exactly as it describes itself. It's a short VN with one non-critical decision and a pretty ok story and conclusion for its length. It won't take you more than 10 or so minutes to give it a look, and considering it's free and you're probably reading this on its store page, why not?  Pros: +Art is pretty good, even if there's not much to see. +Delivers a message you might pay $5+ to see from some other indie game, for free and with less pretension in less time! +Has a pretty fully fleshed out options menu for a 10 minute game. All your VN basics are there including saves and dialog skipping, skip only seen etc. +Multiple language support. +You can buy an extras pack DLC if you want to support the developer. It doesn't contain content locked out from the main game so you won't miss out on anything either. ?Easy perfect game for your steam achievements collection.   Neutral points: =I guessed the twist before I started the game. =The only choice in the game isn't too important since each route can lead to at least one of the other locations you can pick from eventually. You will miss a few scenes if you don't try them all though. =The music isn't great but I also didn't find it annoying. =No voice acting but I'd hardly expect that from a free game and let alone a dev's first VN.  Cons: - There's quite a few grammatical errors, at least in English. I cannot speak for the other languages available.  UPDATE: Eyzi has corrected the mistakes I spotted. -The writing is a little stiff. Would have benefited from some creative writing techniques. It's not all bad though, both Jung and Ai have some character to them. Some.

Carpe Diem is a short, sweet VN with a cute story and an unexpected ending. The story is very, very short, easily read in 5-10 minutes, unless you want to view all the different paths, which all lead to the same ending. It's very enjoyable, and I can't wait to see more of this developer's work. And best of all, it's free! :D

I was hesistant to pick this game up after reading all the reviews. While it is free It is extremely short. However, that is probably it's greatest strength. It's charming and lasts just long enough to be interested in the characters and not bore. Even with the story on the slowest Auto setting I managed to take all three routes within an hour while taking a snack break between each turn. That's right there are only 3 routes, each of which ends the same way. Each playthrough will follow the same general path. The twist at the end tho changed the way I thought about the story during my second and thrid play through.   The story and music were delightful. The only real complaint I have is that there isn't enough art. There are a total of 6 backrounds and you will spend most of that time looking at a slightly changing Ai. There are a few interesting parts to the story that I would have loved to see. For such a short story with such limited content this was a true missed opportunity. All in all I really enjoyed this first attempt and I look forward to how Eyzi, the developer, grows from here.

It's funny how the title itself represent what the creator tries to tell, the meaning of this VN  Carpe Diem in latin means, seize the day  to live life to the fullest, getting the most out of each individual  day.  That is what this game is all about, to stop living in delusion, being depressed, and stressed, instead to live your life to the fullest.  AI is trying to remind us that by the end of the scene. In japanese Ai, means love. And she represent what  love  is for Jung.  12/10 One of the best visual life novels        [Not so old review]  It's been a while since i read this VN I've been helping with the translation on the early days because i find this VN to be awesome.  It is emotionally touching Only needs 15 minute of gameplay to make me feel lonely and empty for the next 5 hours      :')

Hi all,  I liked: It was hilarious to me that the protagonist Jung, did not have a great deal in common with their programmed Ai girl friend, there was friction, sarcasm and antagonism. Which reminds me of the simple truth that opposites attract and yet such differences also cause friction.  Disliked: I simply didn't understand why Jung would question, what he was doing with his life after his Ai girl friend crashed. I had noted that Jung appeared to enjoy her company, despite the considerable limitations of their relationship. Why should his relationship as it was, with some manner of synthetic (software) individual be judged as anyway inferior to any other relationship, real or imagined, synthetic or otherwise? It is evident that many people live their lives in a very lonely fashion, yet PC (Personal Computer) uptake appears to be considerable. Therefore the thought experiment that the game explores, namely human beings developing relationships with Ai software has considerable merit. Many lonely people with access to PCs and such software could develop relationship within the technological constraints of such. I argue then that numerous people's lives could be bettered by the ubiquitous use of such Ai. I suggest that far be it from questioning his own life, Jung, could improve his Ai and eventually with persistence, make a lot of lonely people happier. Maybe even himself. The implied notion that there is a perfect (or even any) partner just waiting for each of us to approach in real life, is naive and I argue, the greatest fantasy associated with this game.   Good gaming, Alter  I suggest that we all enjoy our fantasies, they may be all we have, they may be all we will ever have. I recommend against denouncing them as somehow inferior or unworthy and suggest instead embracing them as part of who we are.

Although I like graphics, the other elements weren't appealing. I would give 'mixed/neutral' review, if possible. The ending is good - it can even explain why on earth all the game is such weird and dull. It's ~650 lines in script.rpy file. That's not too much - that's why it has so many translations.  It's wasted potential in my opinion, but hey, feel free to try yourself and rate!

Frankly, I really like the concept of Carpe Diem, but even for a free game, it doesn't really seem properly fleshed out to be anything more than an interesting distraction. While the game's ending was spoiled for me b the protagonist's name, I did appreciate the other, less obvious bits of foreshadowing in the game. I feel that with better writing and a bit more to the story, Carpe Diem would've been a VN with a standout short story- as it stands, however, I'm a little disappointed.  That said, this is the developer's first game- I want to see the dev make more!

It's a very short visual novel with minimal plot. The plot is nearly non-existent. It's rather unsatisfying. The story feels ham-fisted and clumsily composed. I've seen more plot in a first person shooter than this game. The graphics are all right. Nothing spectacular but still decent enough. The music provides decent atmosphere.
I see what you did there, but It's not working. And if the single point of an ultra short game is not well made... Anyway, thanks for sharing it for free.

This is the visual novel equivalent of flash fiction. You make small talk with another character, and then there's a minor twist at the end, and that's it. Easily finishable within five minutes. Nothing profound here.  The story would be so much better if it had any depth to it. Why is the main character writing the software he's writing? What kind of connection does he want to have with the girl; what's his interest in her? She seems to want his company; why?  Another suggestion: when the girl says she's going to go try on different clothing, it would be nice to actually show her in different clothing.
A pretty picture with endless drivel text. Don't do it.

A flat, uninteresting story, with stereotypical characters. The visuals are decent, but the game seriously lacks in every other way. A decent idea, but just not fleshed out to hold my attention.  If I wanted to go on a shopping trip, I could have just taken my sister and carried her stuff around all day (spoiler...I think?)   The achievement at completion says it all.   ...What AM I doing with my life?  To comment on my playtime: I left the game running while I went to work for a few hours. There's actually no more than 5 minutes worth of game time.

you get one choice, then click your way through....nothing....you just click, anywhere, and text goes by, and then the end. its not a game so much as a illustrated story you make progress by clicking......

Compelling concept behind its message: uninvolved execution.   The reason this review is  negative  is a response to the overwhelming praise this product has received. To be clear, the idea alone is worthy of a positive review in a Steam Store flooded with indulgent dating sims, but the only  positive  aspect s  of the product are meerly conceptual. I hope the author revisits this concept, as it is very worthy of further exploration... (...and if you, Eyzi, happen to be reading this, don't let the big red thumbs-down deter you. XO XO XO)  *Spoilers: but come on, her name is 'Ai'...you can guess where this is heading*  I like the message, at least its concept (that is, a big middle figure to those living their unexamined lives in virtual worlds to escape the torture of critical introspection: sad, pathetic, and heartbreaking), but the concept is the only worthwhile 'thing' in this product—and even then, the concept isn't taken to its full potential, as it is bogged down by its unnecessary attachment to traditional narrative elements after the 'twist' occurs, lessening its potential for impact—e.g.  of course  Jung programmed Ai, adding a degree of separation between the player and Jung (ideally Jung would be playing a dating sim, just like the player himself or herself);  of course  the Turing Test is unnecessarilly included because  Pop-Science!  and Hey, I've seen that term!—and, it must be mentioned, the lack of visual and audio diversity, so get used to the same images and music! They're nice at first, but soon become grating like everything else when it lacks variety! The writing could have been a bit darker, with a few more jabs at the proverbial player through Jung, I only counted one (he only eats ready-made food), but granted, I only explored one of the three narrative branches...though they all end the same, so I felt no need to explore the other two.  Oh, I like how its message is sending existential crises through the discussion page. Maybe I'm a sadist but that alone deserves bonus points.
The real question is- Why did I play this game?
Well... Time to re-evaluate my life. Great game ;c
Must spend a few minutes of your life playing this game! It won't disapoint you@

That Steam Achievement 'What are you doing with your life?' really hit me in the feels. This looked like one of those over-rated artsy fartsy games, however after reading some of the comments I gave this game a try (especially since it's free to play) and it really is a kind of game that makes you ask yourself 'what are you doing with your life?'

This is not a game. A few minutes in and we're given three choices that end up almost being the same. The dialogue was actually pretty interesting and charming, but then the ending was just insulting. There's also little to gain from playing it twice.

Please continue the story. You have something great to build upon.   Ok Im gonna be honest here, It was free and I wanted to try out a entry in the visual novel genre.    ..   I was not dissapointed.   Story 7/10 It is a very simple story as it arcs into one act after another. You are a guy who is dating a girl and throughout the day get to experiance the simple yet cheery atmosphere this girl gives off and+ the love you two have for eachother. (Im gonna end it here because of reasons.) I repeat my statement IT is REALY short but if built correctly this would become a great story. Please continue the story.   Gameplay 8/10 Click. Click. SPACEBAR. In all reality I wasnt expecting much considering I read a few reviews and considering its short story I decided that it wasnt gonna have much for gameplay value.It started out in windowed mode which at 2016 should not even be happening.   Art 6/10 Considering this is their 'first' graphic novel I will give him that the visuals are quite appealing but they are wayy too stagnant. A few times throughout the story there was a lot of the description and nothing that followed through and it let me to a slight dissapointment.   Summary: The story made me reminisce on past loves and struck me at a point of a hard realisation. This is something that books do not get out of me alot. I feel like at the end of this I was reading on something great and I have the massive urge to wanna see the next chapter. I really like this story and would love to see it built upon.   Would I reccomened this game? Yes. but you gotta take it with a grain of salt this isnt for somebody who is expecting 12 hour novel. This is a short 15 minute story with undertones that will grip the reader on a semi deeper level. It teaches you something about humanity and in one way how it works.
A short VN, but it is awesome. It has a sad end, but it gives a good advice..
Heyy, thats pretty good!

Although this story was very short, it was also completely free, so I don't think the length is an issue. The storyline overall was well written, but the actual dialogue felt like it progressed a little too quickly with little transition between topics. The ending evoked the appropriate emotions very well.  All in all, if you have the time to make it through this story (it took me five minutes, but I moved very quickly), and enjoy the genre, then I'd definitely recommend this story as you will walk away satisfied for very little investment.
